items.title: Securing the nuclear fuel supply chain for a growing energy future
items.author: Peter E. Carpenter, Bennett Johnson, Leopold Peiseler, William C. Chueh, Sally M. Benson, Adrian Yao
items.summary:
- Arlington meeting assembled experts from the nuclear fuel cycle to map vulnerabilities and near-term actions to meet rising demand.
- Proposed strategies include supplier diversification, onshoring, material stewardship, advanced analytics, and coordinated policy to reduce bottlenecks and improve resilience.
- The Nature Energy preview notes authorship and affiliations, DOI 10.1038/s41560-025-01931-5, and that full content requires access.

items.title: Historical and future learning for the new era of multi-terawatt photovoltaics
items.summary:
- Historical and future learning for multi-terawatt photovoltaics, linking PV learning, cost reductions, and deployment pathways to rapid decarbonization.
- Covers scalable PV data handling, pattern-transfer printing, ultra-thin glass, recycling and circular economy aims, and datasets from Our World in Data.
- Shows a large multi-institution author group with disclosed industry affiliations and ethics statements.

items.title: Chemical processes and the energy system
items.summary: - Decarbonizing chemistry requires systems-level design beyond catalysts, emphasizing electrification, integration, and hydrogen-system testbeds (20–100 kW) to de-risk scale-up. - Electrification of ammonia/methanol in China with renewables and demand-side management can balance decarbonization with grid security. - Hydrogen's emission-reduction potential varies by use; strongest for ammonia synthesis, biofuels, and steel; weaker for transport, power, heating; underlines need for lab-to-system deployment.

items.title: Grid-scale corrosion-free Zn/Br flow batteries enabled by a multi-electron transfer reaction
items.summary:
- Demonstrates grid-scale corrosion-free Zn/Br flow operation via a multi-electron transfer, boosting energy density and stability.
- Integrates advanced electrodes (carbon-based positive electrodes, MXene carriers, MoS2 arrays) with electrolyte engineering (exclusion–complexation, chelating/zwitterionic additives) to suppress Br2 volatility and self-discharge.
- Addresses practical deployment with low-cost membranes and phase-management, guided by computation-driven design for scalable, durable bromine-based RFBs.

items.title: Interregional transmission can increase reliability while reducing costs and emissions in the US
items.summary: - Uniform ITC 30% across regions: ~39% fewer outages; system cost down ~$0.48B/yr; emissions ~43 Mt/yr lower.\n- Region-specific ITC: ~$2.0B/yr cost savings and ~71 Mt/yr emissions reductions, but reliability gains vary by region; CA may worsen without new lines; TX excluded.\n- More renewables boost savings and emissions reductions under either approach; permitting reform remains a major barrier to transmission expansion.

items.title: Vehicle-to-home charging can cut costs and emissions
items.summary: - Model V2H for 6,480 EVs across 432 US regions; V2H reduces lifetime GHG emissions by 70–250% and charging costs by 40–90%, with some CA/TX cases offsetting costs.\n- Median per-household savings ~$3,800 and GHG reduction ~38 t CO2e; up to 60% of the US population could see net GHG reductions.\n- Policy implications call for user-friendly savings tools, include V2H in planning, rate design, updated building codes, retraining, and transparent battery-degradation reporting.

items.title: Vehicle-to-home charging can cut costs and greenhouse gas emissions across the USA
items.summary:
- Vehicle-to-home/vehicle-to-grid enable EVs with rooftop PV and storage to cut home energy costs and emissions by shifting to low‑carbon periods.
- A nationwide impact depends on grid carbon intensity, tariffs, and the adoption of smart charging and home energy management systems.
- Realizing benefits requires policy support, rate design, and investment in bidirectional charging and grid resilience while managing battery degradation.

items.title: Converting methane into carbon nanotubes and hydrogen in a continuous flow reactor
items.summary:
- Shows co-production of carbon nanotubes and hydrogen from methane in a multi-pass FCCVD reactor under continuous flow.
- Recycling process gas improves efficiency and enables net hydrogen production alongside CNTs.
- Highlights a pathway for integrated CNT/hydrogen production, with Figure 1 illustrating gas recycling.

items.title: Emerging opportunities for high-temperature solid-state and gas-cycle heat pumps
items.summary: - Survey of high-temperature industrial heat pumps, waste-heat recovery, thermal storage (PHES), and low-GWP refrigerants with thermoacoustic/Stirling options. - Caloric-cycle research (magnetocaloric, barocaloric, elastocaloric) with materials/devices, regenerators, and high-temperature Brayton/closed cycles. - TE and HT heat-pump modeling/experiments, liquid metals as HT fluids, preheating strategies, CO2 cycles, and advanced materials.

items.title: AI data centres as grid-interactive assets
items.summary:
- Argues AI data centres can function as grid-interactive assets to support grid flexibility through controllable compute workloads.
- Describes field-testing by Emerald AI with industry partners and provides data/code resources for DVFS-based power management of LLM workloads.
- Contextualizes within data-center energy literature and partnerships (Oracle, NVIDIA, SRP, EPRI) with disclosures and broader impact.

items.title: Atmospheric-pressure ammonia synthesis on AuRu catalysts enabled by plasmon-controlled hydrogenation and nitrogen-species desorption
items.summary:
- Atmospheric-pressure NH3 synthesis on AuRu catalysts achieved under plasmonic activation, with light-controlled hydrogenation and nitrogen-species desorption enabling NH3 formation.
- Operando spectroscopy and kinetic analyses link hot-carrier–driven steps to N2 activation on AuRu and subsequent NH3 release, identifying active sites.
- Frames plasmonic AuRu systems within solar-driven nitrogen fixation as a pathway toward ambient-condition ammonia using earth-abundant metals.

items.title: Centimetre-scale fullerene-free tin-based perovskite solar cells with a 14.51% certified efficiency
items.summary:
- Centimetre-scale tin-based perovskite solar cells use non-fullerene, fluorinated triple-acceptor ETLs (P1–P3) to form uniform, efficient interfaces on large areas.
- P3 delivers top results: 16.06% (0.04 cm2, certified 15.90%) and 14.67% (1 cm2, certified 14.51%), outperforming fullerene ETLs.
- Devices retain >85% efficiency after 550 h under 1-sun illumination, aided by hydrophobic chains and fluorine; multi-institutional data with extensive SI.
